Martin Richard often trot
this is John le gall with the New York
Times and I'm here in Dorchester in the
southern part of Boston this is a
community that is really expensive
tragic sense of loss asthma grieving as
one of the victims the youngest victim
of the explosion at the Boston Marathon
was 8 year old Martin Richard he comes
from a family that was a staple of this
community a very active family and a
family that was well loved and well
liked and well respected earlier today
we spoke to some of his neighbors who
described him as a very loving child the
child who was always out playing just
horrible - you know when you see
somebody so close to home and and to
know it's your neighbor initially plans
were to hold a vigil at a smaller parish
where the family attended church but
officials expected the clouds to be so
large that they moved here to a larger
venue at Garvey park we're just here to
celebrate community one of the
bright spots of tragedies that really
brings out the best in people and that's
what you see here is a community that's
coming together to support a family that
realized a loss that none of us here at
Dorothy Park the sense of community is
palpable
thousands of community members gathered
to pray they held candles they sang
songs they waved flags and you could see
there was definitely grief on the faces
of many of them here as the pastor spoke
about the sense of community the strong
sense of being togetherness and helping
one another what I think all of us know
is that God is present in all of our
lives and we asked if you bless us now
with your gifts of comfort peace and
consolation
